fields.Translation:
1
00:00:00:00 --> 00:00:26:00
Good evening! I hope you are doing well. My name is Hannah and I am talking to you from Namibia. I was born in Ondangwa in Onadjokwe Hospital but, I am from niiwe; however I grew up in Walvis Bay. I currently live and work in Windhoek, the capital city of Namibia.

2
00:00:27:00 --> 00:00:47 
Let briefly tell you how it is like where I am from. What do we eat? Us we eat a lot a diversity of traditional foods such as (she name a few type of foods) from Omusati trees. 

3
00:00:47:00 --> 00:00:57:00 
Now I am going to tell you about our livestock agriculture, we farm with cattle and goats, chicken.

4
00:00:58:00 --> 00:01:05:00 
What are some of the things I love about the place I come from (Owaambo)? I love eating chicken and the thick porridge made from pearl millet flower.
fields.Video Description: This video was recorded by Theron Kolokwe in Windhoek, Namibia, where he and Hannah live. Oshiwambo, also known as Ovango, is spoken by at least 1.4 million people, primarily in the Southern African nations of Angola and Namibia. A Bantu language of the Niger-Congo linguistic family, Oshiwambo is loosely related to more than a thousand other mother tongues throughout the African continent, including Swahili, KiKongo, and Shona. With around half the population of Namibia speaking Oshiwambo, the language boasts a rich diversity of dialects, for two literary standards â€” Kwanyama and Ndonga â€” have been developed, making Oshiwambo an example of what linguists describe as â€˜pluricentric languagesâ€™.
YouTube License Statement: This video is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International license. To download a copy, please contact hello@wikitongues.org.
fields.Geneaology: "[ Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, Benue-Congo, Bantoid, Southern, Narrow Bantu, Central, R, Wambo (R.22) ]"
